The investigation, funded by the Alzheimer's Society, will monitor 140 people with mild cognitive impairment or "pre-dementia" and look at the effects of two lifestyle changes — weight management and resistance training — on their risk of developing dementia.

Experts predict that people aged over 65 will more than double from about 13,000 to about 35,000 by 2025, and triple to more than 55,000 by 2050.

Professor Mark Knott from the University of Birmingham, who is leading the trial, said people are not doing enough to look after their brains.

"The majority of people will go on to lead healthy, productive lives, but the risk of developing dementia does increase as people get older," he said.

"We want to explore whether or not changing people's behaviour and helping them to be more active and lose weight can reduce the risk of developing the condition.

"If we are successful it would open up new options for prevention and treatment of dementia."

The participants will undergo brain scans and have their brains tested for chemical changes — the build-up of beta amyloid plaques that occur before dementia can be detected.

Last year, more than 3,456 incidents involving drones were recorded, compared with only 1,237 in 2015, PA news agency reported. The number of accidents rose from 154 to 221 in the same period, it said.

In a new advisory published last Friday, the UK aviation regulator has warned drone users to expect more drone flying restrictions around airports.

Flying close to an airport can put an aircraft at risk and endanger the lives of the people on board.

Even the drone operators may not be aware of their surroundings. Drones may get lost in low visibility and then crash. This risk is even higher when it gets dark.

In the past year, 21 airports have introduced a risk-mitigation strategy for unmanned aircraft, resulting in 14 such instances of temporary restriction and exclusion of drones within the control zone, CAA said.

Airports in England, Scotland and Northern Ireland will be expected to implement this risk-mitigation strategy by 2020. It is anticipated that a majority of the UK’s airports, including military airfields, will do so by then.
